reviewText:
If feels like somehow a few developers who learned to code from YouTube coding lessons managed to cut and paste their way into something that resembles a game. I’ve tried to like this game for 3 months but its been a horrible experience overall. This is a mediocre game at best. Further, they insist on degrading the user experience further by forcing secondary logins & game registrations.  You have to create an account with them, verify you are who you say you are, and all that junk. This stuff never works right and is especially true with this game. Oh, and get this, you must use a gmail account for registration.  What?? I have gmail but still what kind of flaky spaghetti code are they writing that can only handle registrations from gmail? None of this has anything to do with the game either its just some kind of old school foolishness. They don’t even maintain multiplayer game servers (see below) which would at least be a valid excuse for this account registration nonsense. Aside from registering the game and perhaps being forced to do so multiple times because they have an inadequate registration system that forgets who you are and loses all of your game info you’ll have an even more difficult time trying to do anything that requires hitting their servers like saving race results and getting anything to do with multiplayer to work.  Even the achievements seem straight up bugged presumably because their own system doesn't remember who you are and refuses to pass on the achievement information to Steam.   Even the most mundane of achievements are hit or miss to ever get to pop.  Some basic achievement as simple as opening the car repair menu may never pop and likely a more significant one like a well earned victory achievement will never be realized.  Achievements are not that big of a deal but if you’re going to advertise them as a feature then you know what? They better work.

All this developer imposed nonsense aside, the game itself is average for a 10 year old racing game. The graphics are lackluster but passable.  On the highest settings performance is almost decent BUT it looks so dated. The controls are fine using an XBOX wireless wheel or just a regular XBOX wireless game pad.  What is an issue, however, is once you do any remapping of controls the game menus do not properly represent your remappings. It uses the default prompts in the game even after you change the mappings. It’s also really easy to get stuck in the simplest of menus and the prompts just don’t make sense sometimes. Come on, at least get the MENU system right.  Then it’ll read something along the lines of press A for OK, B for Accept, etc.  So you have multiple options that would appear to do the same thing, but of course they don’t and good luck trying to figure out what the devs were thinking with that.  You can’t tell half of the time if you’re continuing to the next level or about to forfeit a race. Once in a while a button just stops working in the menus. You might have to abandon a race if, for example, you’re on the race stage info menu but the right dpad stops working so you cant navigate back to start the race or tune and repair your car. No other key or button will help either and you’re only choice is to quit which hurts your overall standings which in turn hurts your ability to advance in the campaign. Magically the button starts working again once you've done exactly the opposite of what you wanted to do. Sometimes the sound cuts out entirely. Not just the car sounds, but everything in the game including music, the crowd, etc. Silence. Then it’ll suddenly start working again 30 seconds later. These things have been complained about on the forums for months to no avail.

I’ve never been able to start a multiplayer game.  The system insists I need to create an account and verify it which has been done.  I did it when I first started playing in November 2013 and have done it again since. Doesn't matter I don’t exist apparently.  None of my race results get uploaded and after every single stage of a single player race I face “an error occurred during upload” message.

Support doesn't seem to exist.  They haven’t replied to any emails, facebook, or in the Steam forums. In fact I think some of my posts were wiped away instead of being replied to. The attitude feels like, “thanks for the cash, now leave us alone.”  Also I’d take whatever they put on the store page with a grain of salt. “78 courses in 13 different countries,” they say?  Well maybe if you count that ½ are just reversed courses or slight variations on the other courses. There are nowhere near 78 ORIGINAL courses. Also from the store page, “Online multiplayer mode for up to 16 people” but this is from their own readme: “ARC 4 FIA World Rally Championship has no dedicated servers for multiplayer.” Huh?  So it’s peer to peer? How do you even establish a peer to peer connection if you can’t even start multiplayer mode at all?

There are plenty of great racing games out there with a lower price tag. This game is a bit specialized but not terribly so that its a must have. I guess I could go on about how much I don’t like this game but if you made it this far there is no sense in beating a dead horse. Even though I got it at a big discount I don’t think I’d buy it for $1 if I knew then what I know now.  Since it will be in my Steam library for eternity I guess I’ll just rage play it whenever I’m debating buying another game that I’m on the fence about to remind me to stop buying terrible games.

reviewText:
I'm a huge rally fan and for me, this game ticks some boxes but is lacking in key areas.

Gameplay experience is generally good, I play in the hood view and its easy to get enjoyment from the sense of speed it creates. The car set up option is also good and fairly thorough.
The handling of the cars (I use a controller) is, although, a bit sloppy and I would've liked the kind of percision evident in games like the DiRT series.

My biggest problem and the most frustrating thing about this game is the pace notes. If you arent very familiar with rally outside the gaming world, perhaps this wouldn't seem like a big thing. The pace notes in game are HORRIFICALLY inaccurate and vague. The developers clearly gave little thought to individual stages and instead recorded all the notes and threw them in haphazardly into the rallys with little thought. Many of the corners in game tighten and are rarely mentioned, to get out of recording specific stage notes, there is a chicane (left/right or right/left) note and a very vague Turn Left/ Turn Right junction note with no specific severity of bend. Without a course map it becomes extremely difficult to successfully navigate a stage as crests and tightening corners are never mentioned and its largely left to guess work.

I could go on about the various problems with this game but the fact of the matter is if youre looking for a decent rally simulator with good gameplay, great graphics, and decent gaming experience, buy DiRT.
This game has a long way to come before it can compete.

reviewText:
I feel somewhat torn about this game. On the one hand it is a competent rally game we had not since Colin McRae Rally 2005 and Richard Burns Rally. On the other hand it has some serious flaws. The game has quite arcady driving physics, and if it is good or not for you, it depends on your personal preferences. This is a proper rally game, so it does not have any Ghymkhana, rallycross or baja nonsense. It contains 4 classes (WRC, WRC 2, WRC 3 and Junior WRC) and 13 rallies with 6 special stages each.

On the other hand the amount of roads is quite limited. Each rally has 6 stages, but there are driven mostly through the same pieces of road, so there are only about 2 unique special stages per rally. The fact that kept us playing old rally games was great amount of special stages and vehicles, there just is not enough of that. The game is capped to 30 frames per second, what is unacceptable for a PC driving game nowadays, but there are some methods to remove this cap. The game still has some bugs, which are not game braking, but still can be annoying for some people.

The bottom line is that if you are into rally games, get it on sale. It has too much flaws to be recommended at full price, but if you can get it cheaper, it is worth playing.

NOTE : My play time on this game is around 100hours, but i play offline, which steam does not count, hence the low 'time playing'.

I will recommend this game, HOWEVER:
There are several things very much worth taking into account if you do want to buy it.

1. The co-driver is terrible. Is often quite inconsistent with the labelling (i.e a left 3 can be several different angles and speeds even though all of them are in the same stage)
He will mention stuff thats irrelevant, one corner saying 'past trees' whe the tree in question is on top of an 8 foot wall, which you should also avoid but is NOT mentioned.
He NEVER says anything about camber which is a little odd, he will call jumps bumps, bumps jumps and jumps as crests, with no real consistency between any of the three, and will often not mention bumps and crests that can end up with race destroying crashes.
He appears to have very little idea what opens or tightens means, and will say them when not needed, and not say when he really really should have done.
Rolling the car on corners that should be 'Don't cut' is quite common place, and i'm pretty sure (i've checked it twice) there is a Hairpin labelled left when its right.
This can get insanely annoying after a while, when it is well known good rallying is all about good pace notes.
Basically he is quite inconsistent, and you will find youself simply learning the courses by doing them, and having your own pace notes in your head for the ones he doesn't mention.
There are no also no options for altering him other than timing and volume.

2.The number of tracks mentioned is somewhat of a false hood, there seems to be around 3 stages for each country, that get 'combined together' into different tracks, (so the first half of one track is the last part, ot the middlle of another), and just having the reverse stage as another track (so driving the same course backwards). While the 'weather' changes, it is just a difference of colour, not sunny to raining, just midday to evening and only seems to affect lighting comditions.

3. Someone else has said this aswell, this is a hairpin fest like no other, I beleive there are 2  maybe 3 courses. where the car gets to really high speeds, aside from those you will never see 5 or 6th gear. Every single course has a bucket of hairpins, and very few fast sections even in Germany, Finland, Australia and Sweden, which are kind of renowned for being very high speed events.

Aside from these points the game handles quite alot better than other WRC games,  the car physics are very good and you can feel the road and behaviour of the car quite nicely.
Basically this game plays quite nicley but has some not major but very irritating flaws.

reviewText:
I have played this game a decent amount and while it's not terrible it's not great either.

The game looks somewhat decent, I personally have found no bugs that way. The physics are very, very far away from being a true simulation. Front wheel drive cars do not actually behave like they are front wheel drive. You have to try to actually make them understeer. The different road surfaces do not always feel all that different either, the cars never seem to lack grip no matter what surface you are on. There are occasional issues with physics that make you spin in weird directions too ( like turning right and grabbing the handbrake and the car suddenly spins left).

Car tuning is very basic and does not save between stages. Big changes to the setup of a car don't effect it that much. No choice of tires, no varible weather. I feel that even with steering lock at maximum the car always seems to react slowly to my input (xbox 360 controller). The car just turns to slowly even when you move to full travel of the stick you wait for the car to catch up.

Tracks are generic, all of the stages are the previous stage reversed or pieces of the other stages combined ( apparently they all take place in the same 3-5 mile stretch of road) which is an issue I had noticed in the previous WRC games. The stages are a great deal longer than those in Dirt 3. In Dirt 3 the stages are over far to fast and never really felt like a rally, this does improve on that at least. Co-driver is not always synced with the track and can be telling you about the corner you are currently in not the next one even with maximum delay. Some of the co-driver notes are wrong also ( saying left for a right turn, hairpins when its really a 2 or 3 etc.)

The Career is far to easy IMO. I have played on the hardest settings from day 1 and never really had an issue winning any stage. I was able to skip WRC3 completely and even when driving a lower performing" car in the same class I had no problem beating the other cars by 10secs or more per stage.

The game is not all bad

reviewText:
6/10 – Great when it works but do not buy for full price.
Pros – Great visuals, tight fun controls, great new career structure, authentic audio and atmosphere
Cons – Broken multiplayer, constant crashing, inconsistent frame rates, career progress can erase itself, plenty of recycled content.
---------------------------------Full Review
Annual games are becoming more of a norm now a days as developers push less risky ideas and even though I am not the biggest fan, I do approve if it is done right. To be able to introduce enough new ideas on an annual basis to warrant such a yearly purchase is hard, but not impossible.

Sadly the WRC series is not such a series. It was made extremely clear to me by WRC 2 (2011) that recycling content was a normal thing. Now, 4 years since the first of the WRC games I still feel the effects. But fear not, as this year’s game feels fresher than ever. Whether or not this is acceptable however, is up for debate.

WRC 4 starts right out of the gate with a few very welcome changes. Gone is the boring dreary campaign that forces you to slowly crawl up the ranks. In WRC 4 you can get to the top level of the WRC in only a few hours, but also allows you to go down to the lower levels if you wish. This gives you a bit of freedom in your style of play. Like the real series, the higher the division of the WRC you compete in the more events are played out before seasons end. So by the time you compete in the top level you will be running the whole official calendar before one of these seasons is over.

This year the developers went with authenticity; something that is always welcome in an official racing game. Everything from the main menu (which shuffles real slow motion shots of rallies past) to the 3 day breakdown of each rally makes the game feel more realistic then it ever has.  The stages themselves too feel far more varied. Most rallies have a unique flavour to them. Finland is flying with many blind crests, and the UK has deep mud and rain. Gone is the mirrored feeling of many of the stages in previous games. Instead you are fought with tight hairpins, and Cliffside falls. This gives the game a sharper feel of power and control; allowing the player to truly push as hard as he dares.

Even though the new stages are impressive, many issues around come into focus. Some of which has never been addressed since the very first game. The main issue is replicating certain turns. Although not as bad as previous games or the horridly copied game that was WRC 2, there are still many segments that have either been seen before in previous game or are blatantly taken from other rallies! I found a perfect example with an uphill double hairpin that was in Sweden and then again in Australia. I have never had a problem with reusing the same stages in different configurations to create multiple runs of one rally, but to copy the same turns and then paste them elsewhere in a supposed other country is just irritating. It creates a heavy sense of déjà vu, creating fast player fatigue.

The audio in game also creates a step forward for the series. Gone are the horrible electronic songs that felt wildly out of place and instead you hear more of a smooth sounding beat. The problem here however is that there is only one song. You think they could have added a few more. Worse than the single song soundtrack is the horrible co-driver which makes a shocking 4th straight appearance in this series. They have not changed the horrible sounding co-driver… EVER. This being a rally game your co-driver is essentially to the game. You have to listen to him to know what is coming up. The problem here is he sounds so mechanical that it is hard to get into a groove. He says turns in such a choppy fashion I am dumb founded that the developers have not made a better sounding co-driver after 4 flipping games! He also has a tendency to call notes too late causing you to miss a turn.  I guess they never expected people to drive faster than the co-driver.
On a positive side for the audio is not all bad. The engine sounds are a big plus. All WRC cars sound very unique from one other making them a joy to listen to. From the smooth gear shift of the DS3 to the harsh pop shift of the Polo, it’s a real treat to listen to the vehicles in action.

This year’s game has also taken a huge step up graphically. Even though it is still not even close to the level that which was set by Codemasters DiRT games, it is still a hefty step up from last year’s visuals. The damage model however is still lacking and the water effects are still pathetic but other than that the game looks great.

The problem with the game is: it clearly is not ready to be sold. The game is littered with broken content; the main one of which is multiplayer. To enter multiplayer you first must register for their online service. This pointless step forces people to register their username and emails before entering. This also complicates things as they do not tell you this in any shape or form upon attempting to get online. Instead upon entering multiplayer they will notify you that your “nickname” is incorrect. It wasn’t until I used help forums that I realized I had to register prior to entering online. You would think that once registered that would be that, but it gets better: once I registered I was able to play online for only 3 days at which point again they told me my nickname was incorrect. I am not interested in re-authenticating my email 2 times a week for their stupid system. What little time I was in online events I would frequently encounter game crashes and disconnections. What little I played online told me that the online structure is a very basic model. With up to 16 playera and offering only ghost vs game play it is not worth the pain of entry. Online simply doesn’t work; sufficed to say, I have given up on it. These issues continue in other modes however. My final straw was when the game erased my career for seemingly no reason.

Now I did start this by stating the series is NOT a good contender for the yearly model which might seem odd as most I have said so far was positive apart from some broken content. The game is a step up for the most part and the game (when it runs) is really fun and tight, but you don’t buy an apple for a few bites and that’s what this game is: a few bites and nothing more. A game that struggles this much to bring working content and not requiring constant recycled content should not need to release a game on a yearly basis.

I would recommend this game ONLY if it is not listed for full price. What the game offers is amazing, but losing my career and not being able to play online is enough for me to not recommend it to people who want the complete experience. A series like this needs to take a year off and rethink its strategy.

I give this game a 6/10. It is really fun and the game play is really enjoyable but with only half the content working it’s hard to recommend it to everyone.

reviewText:
There's much to like about this game. The car handling is fine for my tastes (which run towards the arcade more than the sim as I play with a keyboard) and there are different classes represented, making for a good career mode. The rallies are characterful and distinct and sometimes beautiful, and the stages are good fun to drive, and generally quite twisty and narrow - which is good in a rally game.

There are some things that could be improved. The game feels clunky on my computer, which is up to the task of running Bioshock Infinite but lags sometimes in this game with the lighting effects. The menu systems are clumsy. I like the fact that stages are run as pairs between services, as this somewhat replicates the WRC experience, but the damage system is too generous. In games like Colin McRae Rally 4, choosing parts to repair became quite a strategic decision, especially when the car was fairly easily damaged in stages with jumps. The pacenotes are vague as well, but that's not a problem unique to this game.

My biggest frustration is one that might not concern a casual gamer too much, but it concerns the design of rallies. Although the individual stages themselves are good, the developers are not true to the WRC experience when they take names that in real life belong to entirely different stretches of road and use them to label a stage that is a minor variation of a previous one. And that is how the rallies are organised - different permutations of the same little patchwork of roads, with each section reused over and over again. Of course, WRC events often repeat stages - so why doesn't the game do it in the same way, if the developers must reuse stages? Instead of doing something like using the Col de Turini and St. Bonnet names for very similar stages (when in real life they refer to stages hundreds of kms apart), just have Col de Turini 1 and Col de Turini 2. And make the second pass over the stage different - different weather and a surface that reflects the passage of the rally route. For me, this annoyance reduces the replay value of the game, but I would still recommend it to anybody with an interest in motorsport.

reviewText:
I'll give a quick run-down of my experiences, but I'd thoroughly recommend you look elsewhere for a rally or even just car game. This is not a good place to look for any accuracy in how the cars perform or react to different conditions.

Pros:
Career Mode is nice, relatively fleshed out.
Track variation; it doesn't re-use the same level with different portions cut out for a 'different' track layout.
Neither Good/Bad:
Graphics are dated, but it's a rally game. They have looked quite good for a while now.
Slowdowns in the menu whenever the menu overlay is visible. The in-race performance is quite a bit better than this.
No different weather conditions on tracks, or night. You're stuck with Dawn, Noon, Dusk and whatever weather they decided to stick on the track.
Cons:
Physics feel like you're driving on vaseline, huge lack of feedback from the track(if there's a ditch you'll notice though) and slapstick-like reactions to any sort of collision without any semblance of weight. This lack of semblance of weight carries through to handling as even heavy cars feel like they are merely gliding across the track's surfaces. There is no fighting at the edge of what a car can do.
Sounds seem to be very short samples that noticeably loop. This, along with a lack of differentiation between the bonnet view and driver view's sound levels makes it a chore to listen to. The co-drivers' voices are muffled and distorted on top of this, making them hard to hear at the default levels.
What the Co-driver says does not always match up to the track, or the visual representation of what they're saying. This visual representation is also often wrong, especially for chicanes.
There has been no post-release support, and longstanding issues have not been fixed in a patch. Do not expect this to change for anything you experience in-game that is detrimental to your enjoyment of this product.
This is my view from having played it. I'd like to like it, but the lack of physicality regarding the cars just makes me cringe.

reviewText:
I own and enjoy the first WRC game by the same developers which came out in 2010, so I thought I would get this when I saw it cheap in a sale for 80% off.

The game seems to have changed little since then  - the graphics are slightly improved but not much.  In some respects I think I prefer the original's graphics which aren't quite as colourful perhaps, but look more realistic as a result.

There is still no weather to speak of, most stages are dry with clear skies - no heavy downpours or snowstorms here, something which the Colin McRae Rally games had since the late 1990s!  I would say that Colin McRae Rally 2005, in fact even Colin McRae Rally 3, had better graphics than this game as well despite being much older.  Unfortunately Codemasters stopped making semi-realistic rally games like that, and went full arcade.  Dirt 1 was still somewhat realistic but by Dirt 3 it dropped any pretense of realism and lost me entirely.  If you hanker after old school rally games like the Colin McRae series then WRC is all that's on offer today.  I would say it's better than Dirt 3 (except graphically) but inferior to the others.

The car handling seems to have taken a step back since the first WRC game and the cars are now much harder to drift without using the handbrake - even full throttle while steering on ice it is very hard to get the car to drift, perhaps this was dumbed down to make the game 'easier' and more casual but it makes the cars less satisfying to drive for me.  (I did make sure stability assist was turned off.)

There are 6 stages per country but in my view this is very misleading because essentially, and I'm not exaggerating unfortunately, all stages look and play the same.  You don't have the feeling of progressing across a country but of driving the same tiny part of it, 6 times!  It's really very lazy I'm afraid.  Also the stages have FAR too many corners and not enough straights - the first WRC game and indeed real life WRC isn't like this.  So you are constantly bombarded with corner after corner after corner which becomes monotonous and tiring, and there are none of the exhilarating exciting super fast sections of the first game.

WRC 4 lacks the group B cars of WRC 1, like the RS200 which is disappointing.

Overall the game feels like a budget release, despite its full price tag and I would only recommend getting it when heavily discounted, and even then you probably won't be fully satisfied with it.

I gather that WRC 5 is coming out this year but by new developers.  Hopefully they will put a lot more effort, polish and love into their game than this has had.

reviewText:
Firstly, let's just make two things clear: this game was released in October 2013 - it costs, currently, £24.99.

Now, bearing in mind the release date, you might expect the game to look fairly nice. It doesn't. At all. It's passable for 2005, but in 2013 I expected a little more, and considering how dull and uninteresting the game appears visually, my PC kicks out volumes of heat when playing it - perhaps that's due to not using the game's v-sync option which locks the frame-rate at an absurd and choppy 30FPS. It's that, screen-tearing or using a third-party tool to force v-sync. Again, 2013 - £24.99.

At least the game works, until it hangs on menu screens, or until upon loading a stage it goes deadly silent unless you're willing to exit out and start it up again. A couple of bugs, we can look past those.

The gameplay, though, is where it counts, and for WRC 4, where it fails further. There is no satisfaction to be found here. In a rally we have six stages, most of which are the same stage, just with different start/finish lines, and all of which are drab and unappealing. The driving gives no palpable sensation of the road you're on, the jumps are floaty, the layouts are packed with hairpins (I hope you like the sound of the rev-limiter), your co-driver bleats monotonous directions at you, and irritatingly, loves to comment when you can't pick the road texture out from the not-road texture and drive into things: whoa

For the short version; This game is pretty bad, not worth it's WRC license.


Decided to finally give it a go. I had quite a lot of fun with WRC2 a few years ago, hoping that this would continue on it. Well, and that is exactly what it does, and not in a positive way. It is common that wen developers get the hang of a license, they improve on it, but not with Milestone!

Graphics are pretty bad, they would be doable in 2007-2008, but we are quite a few years past that. The game literally has no graphic settings apart from V-Sync, FXAA and resolution and there are very few settings outside of that as well. To make matters worse this game is performing like absolute crap and is capped at 30FPS.
I also had borders on my 1680x1050 resolution, I mean, seriously? I can understand it in videos because of the way they are rendered but i was having those borders in the actual game itself.

The menus look rather cheap and with me the background videos werent playing properly. Could be my graphics card, but still, the first time I actually had issues with videos not playing properly.

And then we get to setting up a driver. I don't know what they are thinking over at Milestone but it is very common to have a last name of more than 9 letters. It's sad that in 2013, game devs(only Milestone, apparently) are still not adapting to longer text boxes. Seriously, even old games had text boxes to 16 characters, but not with Milestone! This small thing just shows the abysmal quality of the game engine.

Driving physics are doable and there is enough in terms of setup.

Sounds is bad, but better than the average game. I don't know what they did with the Co-Driver, though, but I wouldn't call it good.

The stages seem okay, although I seem to be getting a lot of the same parts. It seems like they have just reused the same parts over and over again.

The pacenotes are pretty bad and are hardly ever correct, I've come across so many errors and inconsistencies in the pacenotes that there is very little point in actually listening to them.

And if you are thinking of making an error and rolling down a cliff, something that is always a danger in real world WRC, don't worry, the game will reset you before you're actually falling down!

This game is pretty abbysmal and way, way behind in tech. This game is just not worth it's WRC license.

reviewText:
The game's got potential, but feels like it's been made by someone that just didn't give a beep.

First off, the console port is poorly pulled off. You can't use your mouse despite the curser being presented ingame.
The keys you need in the menus are at times awkward (enter to select and space to activate? the opposite of most games). Sometimes you need to press odd, nonconfigurable buttons to do things. Most things work with arrow keys, but then you need to find F2 all of a sudden etc.
There's damage in the game, but it doesn't properly work. Sometimes you can race into a wall at 100km/h and just drive on without damage. Also damage doesn't seem very pronounced while driving.
You have to select your manager, but whom you take seem not to matter, and they're not voice acted and just leave standard template messages without emotion. So basically you just pick the name to fill into the templates.
Speaking of templates - during loadscreens there are 'interviews' with other players. However they have very few lines to say, and these are even shared between different opponents, so you get bored of em before you've completed your second rally.
There's also a reputation system in place to manage which things you've got access to, but even when you win all stages you're being sent along a very linear path without any true freedom of choice.
After a rally you're presented with a newspaper detailing what's going on in the four different classes available. However sometimes when you're looking at a class other than the one you're in, the template will beep up and just display something like %%S01_AI2_Points%% Points ahead of %%S01_AI3_Name%% etc.
The text describing the teams doesn't seem to have been proofread or using templates that make it obsolete. I noticed one of the WRC2 teams was described as driving a Subaru, but the car depicted was a Mitsubishi.
The steam achievements seem to have been an afterthought. You get an achievement for doing the most mundane things, like opening your repair screen. But you don't get any for doing extraordinary things. I tried to drive the Spain WRC Junior rally without using repairs or rewinds, and won. But nothing popped up other than the one for completing the rally.
Speaking of rewind. There's that in the game, as expected in this day and age. But if you rewind and keep the brake button down, you'll not brake, you'll actually reverse. I'm assuming that's a bug.
And now we're at bugs, I don't think they've cared about any that didn't crash the game. The water animation for water patches, at least in mexico, are sometimes running the wrong way, making water seem to go uphill. According to Newton, this isn't meant to be.
Every time you complete a special stage (which seems to be the only part of rally being in the lackluster career mode), you get an error message about uploading your stats. I haven't found a way for it to stop trying to upload my data somewhere I haven't given consent to yet.
I'm sure with a little bit of tweaking, this could've been a good game, but considering it came up last year and I still find all those errors, they can't be bothered doing so. If the game's sold at 2€ or so, try it out, but expect an indie game, not a professional release by a well funded publisher.

The game isn't terrible, but if this was a codemasters product, it'd not have been released.

reviewText:
While I don't usually think of myself as a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, in this particular instance I'm almost forced to be given the fact that the graphics in this game are terrible compared to your DiRT 3s et al.

I've also come across those who claim DiRT 3 is more of an arcade-style racer whereas this is more of a simulation, however this couldn't be further from the truth. If you wanted to play a proper rally simulation, then you'd look no further than Richard Burns Rally which will test your ability to even drive along a straight line for more than a couple of seconds.

So where does that leave WRC 4 exactly?

Well Codemasters have had years of experience creating games that hit the right balance between gameplay/playability and realism (including the likes of TOCA and even Micro Machines), however WRC 4 seems to want to accelerate in a direction that facilitates neither of these core features; obviously content in the hopes that the WRC license alone would be enough to carry it through. Well it doesn't work I'm afraid.

Also throw into the mix the weird sound effects which sound 'tinny' due to its poor quality and implementation, and what you're left with is a game that couldn't possibly be recommended to anyone.

My advice to those seasoned in the Genre would be to disable all driving-assists, set the difficulty to 10 and damage to Heavy. Those are the settings I play on (using a 360 pad) and I find it to be a good challenge.

reviewText:
I'm changing my review. I've been playing WRC5 (on xbox) and after playing that, I really appreciate this game a lot more. WRC4 is way better than the all new WRC5!

First up, this isn't Dirt Rally. If you want a super-realistic rally experience go and buy that and don't look back. If you're looking for arcade rally, this is the best you'll find. It's got a lot of stages, plenty of official cars and drivers and nicer looking environments than WRC5.

It's got real 'one more go' appeal.. you may, if you're anything like me, aim to stop playing at 9pm and not notice as 1am rolls by and you're still rallying. It's fun, addictive and fast.

BUT.. there is a but. The bugs...

Now that we have refunds on Steam, if you're after an arcadey rally game you should try this regardless of its biggest bug, the sound problem. That is, myself and quite a few others experienced a sound problem where the sound only worked for one rally stage, then it broke and you have to restart the game.. but if you find that this sound issue happens to you, you can just refund it and be no worse off. You'll know before the 2 hours are up whether or not your system is affected by it. Play a few stages and see if it breaks. If not, you're good.

It's disappointing that the devs don't communicate with anyone, or that they didn't patch this game (I think we only got 1 or 2 patches at the most despite bugs) but it's such a good game that it really is a struggle for me to know whether to recommend it or not. I love playing it.

It's also disappointing that the online leaderboards don't work at all. You just get an error at the end of every stage telling you the game can't access scores or something. This should have been fixed. In fact, why aren't they using the Steam API like everyone else!???!!

I believe this is still the best arcadey pure rally game we have (second would be probably have to be Dirt 3, of course, but you have to put up with all that other rubbish to get to the rally stuff).. I'd say it's even better than Seb Loeb, for arcade rally fun. This doesn't have rallycross, though. If you want that, get Seb Loeb or Dirt Rally instead.

I've played this game mostly with an xbox controller, but my Logitech G27 works great with it and it's a fun drive in 3rd person or 1st person views. If you have a different wheel to the G27, though, it's hard to know whether or not it will work. Give it a shot and see but remember the refund policy because this game won't be seeing any patches in the future.

The downside is that the publishers don't seem to care about its customers and there are bugs that should have been fixed. BUT I've loved playing it.. so give it a go but be sure not to play more than 2 hours if that sound problem occurs because it will never get fixed. Just refund it if you hit this problem. If not, enjoy a great arcade rally game that's wayy better than the big mess that is WRC5.
